THE EVENING SUN, BALTIMORE,
Pertinent Portraits
div1.p: GEORGE W. GOETHALS

There is a particular thing about
George W. Goethals' handling of the
canal job that tops all other considera-
tions and which has been heretofore
overlooked. This is his sticking to it
from the moment he assumed command,
in 1906. This is the real diagnosis of
his success.

Whatever may have been the true
motive of Wallace's for getting off the
job, or of the collapse of the Stevens
era, there remains the fact that there
was an underlying vein of opinion that
the American handling of the canal
would meet with the same fate of scan-
dal--if not in a greater degree--as the
regime of the French.

Whether he stuck from innate deter-
mination, or because--bearing in mind
the traditions of the service--he real-
ized that it would be an irreparable
blow to his military career, matters lit-
tle. Both incentives probably influenced
his actions more or less.

But he persevered and gave the per-
manence, the stability to the organiza-
tion that was needed at that time, and
needed woefully. For no one knows
better than the 1905 and 1906 and 1907
men how easily they might have been
led to other fields--at least away from
the Panama field.

And no one knows better than the
men of the early days of the American
handling how they felt that the task
was not an eight or ten year one, but
a twoscore year job. They had their
misgivings, and justly. No one but
the worker of those days can appreciate
the terror that the fever put into the
men. Successfully to see their compan-
ions' places vacant each new morning
put the dread into them all.

Even then they all had mild phases of
the fever, which, combined with the
early system of sanitation and the lack
of wholesome food at the messhouses,
was sufficient to throw the “shakes” into
any man.

Many looked on the original creation
of the Isthmian Canal Commission as a
monumental joke, and a mere bailiwick
for otherwise “lame-ducks”--and end-
less, potential, gorgeous pork-barrel of
pickings. In Goethals' demands for more
men and more money there appeared to
many only the opportunity of rewarding
political service at home.

In 1907 Goethals was begging for a
paltry $14,000 to enlarge and better
equip the shops at Gorgona, for the re-
pair of the steam shovels and mechanical
equipment. And with the chances
against him, he was pleading for five ad-
ditional steam shovels.

This merely suggests--though elo-
quently--the difficulties he encountered,
aside from the personal irritations of the
commissioners themselves, who sat in
the Washington office as long as they
consistently could.

The resignations of Wallace and
Stevens may have been, as hinted at the
time, one of the manifestations of the de-
sire of the transcontinental roads to
thwart the project. Or they may have
been induced by the petty interference
on the part of the original canal board;
or by the disappointment at finding ir-
revocable the requirement that the chief
engineer give his personal supervision
on the Isthmus.

Stevens' unexpected action in getting
off the works, following so closely on
Wallace's quittance--after Wallace had
been the subject of such a string of com-
mendation on his determination, and
Stevens had received even a higher rat-
ing in tenacity and stick-to-itiveness--
had a depressing and disrupting effect
on the canal workers.

And it is not exaggeration to say that
back in the comprehensions of the two
chief engineers lay the real truth of
their going; a truth that could not but
reach the workers--that neither Wallace
nor Stevens believed the canal project
feasible, however much money might be
poured into the enterprise. A failure
would schedule their reputations for a
warping; for it is difficult to imagine
that either Wallace or Stevens would
have willingly surrendered such an op-
portunity for fame and constructive
achievement had he not felt the task to
be a superhuman one.

Now that the canal is an accomplished
fact, one can only conjecture what their
feelings are, what regret is theirs, what
anathema to unrecognized opportunity,
what execrable lack of forehandedness
and foresightedness.

But Goethals--Lieutenant Goethals
that was, an obedient disciplinarian,
with not even the rating of a full regi-
mental body--he accomplished the feat.
He drove the impossible to the feasible.
He builded from the bench-mark of per-
sistence. Summed up, his engineering
ability will be found to have had the
least to do with the result, his executive
ability to have had as scant a share in
it. He himself gives free credit to pre-
vious planning for the operation of the
“simultaneous level” working in Cule-
bra Cut; he allows former Division Engi-
neer of the Central Division Louis
Rourke the credit for the intricate track
layout for the “serving tracks” and
dumping trackage; to Col. H.H.Hodges,
second in command, he gives unqualified
praise for the designing of the lock
system.

Patience, bulldogedness, tenacity--
whatever term is used--was the key-
stone, the grand motif. Deep in his heart
Goethals must have realized his direct
impotence, but also he must have real-
ized and appreciated and must have been
guided by the one compelling impulse.

It was the scintillating crux of the
problem, in itself a veritable achieve-
ment of genius. It was the Napoleonic
one of mere mass: just fire as many
men and as many dirt trains and steam
shovels onto the job and into the job
as the people at home will stand for,
and more than they will stand for will-
ingly. And keep firing them in. Some-
thing will have to happen. It will cost
money and it will cost men; but keep
filling up the gaps. Increase the rein-
forcements; hang onto the line:

It was the Germanic spirit of '70-71
reincarnate; the spirit that saw past
Spicheren and the Saarbruck setbacks
to Metz and Sedan; to the ever-concen-
tering files about Paris-sur-la-Seine.

Goethals' persistence and earnestness
impressed the commissioners finally--as
well as our nation--with the sincerity
of his efforts and plans and his innate
leadership; and by 1909 the spirit of ac-
complishment was visible to all. Some-
thing had happened.

It was a wonderful patience that
glimpsed the clearing away of the Isth-
mian chaos, the leveling of the hills,
the disposal of the unimaginable bulk
of spoil; that foresaw the rise of the
mile and a half dam across the Chagres'
plain; that grasped the controlling of
the fearful torrential rains and Chagres'
floods to a man-serving utility.

It was a wonderful patience that
withstood the terrible, constant strain,
to “get from out and under.” It was
supreme Goethals patience. H. L. W.
